In 2011, persistence of vision had already been revised twice, in two papers written by cognitive film scholars Barbara and Joseph Anderson, and published in 1978 and 1993. There is a lot of psychological literature about motion perception to support their idea that the notion of persistence of vision is a myth. I think Veritasium still owes its public a fine grain revision of their 2011 explanation.

interesting point to be noticed-the camera has a form of persistence of vision itself. If you pause the video while the ball is flashing but held steady, the image will still show it as the mixture of colors. If the frame rate was high enough without persistence, then each time you paused you would only see what color LED was lit up at the time. There is some variance in the color, but i think most people likely noticed that even while the video was running, it wasn't a solid purple but rather flashed between light and dark purple rapidly. Maybe this ball could be used to test different cameras to work on improving their quality

Actually this effect is used in projectors - they display every frame as a sequence of reddish, greenish and blueish image.
And this is why, when you quickly move your eyes all small white spots de-mix into R, G and B.

Similar thing is used in most TVs and monitors, but here different colours are lit up simultaneously - very close to each other.
(This definitely applies to LCDs and OLEDs, but I'm not sure about CRTs - they display image with just one light point travelling through whole screen, but they also have this luminescent panel which may be not so instant)

It's not the brain that blends the colors but rather the bipolar and ganglion cells of the retina of the eye "add up" the signals of the rod and cone photoreceptor cells (actually, subtracting, see below).
Think of it this way:  let's imagine that we have two balls, one is identical to the one in the video, emitting red, green, and blue light; the other is a glass ball containing hydrogen gas stimulated to emit a bright line spectrum at 410 nm (a pretty color toward the blue end of the spectrum often called "purple" or "violet").
The eye will see both balls as the same color.  How does this happen?  The eye has 3 kinds of cone cells (S, M, and L) that are sensitive to S(short, peaking at 420nm, blue), M(medium, 530nm, green), and L(long, 560nm, red) and also rod cells, which peak at 500nm.  (The visible spectrum goes from 400 to 700nm.)  Through the "opponent process of color vision" (google that term for more info) the rods and cones of the retina send signals to the bipolar cells, which stimulate the ganglion cells, which send a signal down the optic nerve that is basically the difference between the red and green, blue and (red and green [aka yellow]) and black and white.  The single frequency input of 410nm has the same output as the output when the input is (approximately, and intensity of each frequency matters as well) 390nm, 530nm, and 560nm.  The human eye and brain work very differently than a CCD camera and computer to capture and process and image.

Maybe we see purple because of the opponent process theory. It says we can't perceive a reddish-green color therefore with this ball we can only perceive the blue and red combination when it is still. Since it goes in the order of green to red (not red to green to blue like the guy said) the theory also suggests that when one pair of stimulus is activated then removed then we see the opponent as an afterimage. This leaves us to see more red blended with the blue to give purple.

At what frequency are the red, green, and blue lights switching on and off? The ability of human eye to continue to see the image of an object for a very short duration of time even after the removal of the object is Persistence of Vision. The persistence of eye vision is 1/16th part of a second.
PRACTICAL USE:-
It is due to the persistence of vision that we are able to see movie pictures in a cinema hall. The still pictures in the form of a long film are projected on the screen at a rate of about 24 pictures per second. Under these conditions, the image of one picture persists on the retina of eye till the image of next pictures falls on the screen, and so on. Due to this, the slightly different images of the successive pictures present on the film merge smoothly with one another and give us the feeling of moving images.

One practical application of this is in an LED sunrise alarm clock. The light gradually "brightens" over the course of an hour. It can be done either by changing the current through the LED (which is much harder to do as the perceived intensity of light varies as an inverse-square relationship to the actual intensity) or by varying the time between successive pulses of light. If the light pulses at more than 120? Hz it's indistinguishable to the human eye from a still light.

This is about human perceptive limits. A similar thing happens with our visual resolution -- how small a detail we can make out clearly. It may seem like a disappointment to not make out very small details, but then again, it "enables us" to perceive levels of gray when we look at a B&W photograph composed of only black dots of various size. I guess that's why they call such images "halftones" because they are only make of black and white, and not true tones of gray. Of course this effect is happening in color photos too, with "screens" of cyan, magenta, yellow and black dots, but I have a fondness for thinking about B&W halftones. Without that human perceptual limit, how would communication and culture and world history have been different. I guess we'd have to use thousands of more words, since there might not be a good picture to replace them!

Short answer:  Each color is on for a specific period of time giving you a "volume" of red, green, or blue. Your eyes "sum" them up based on the "volume" rather than the duration; each of which is shorter than you can see individually. Look closely at your monitor.

Long answer:  Look up "Pulse Width Modulation" (PWM) and apply it to each red, green, and blue. This is the same technique used for digitally dimming lights, controlling motor speed, and temperature of electric heating processes.

That will only happen if the camera's sampling rate, which is 30 samples per second, is at least twice as fast as the color change rate. 
So for the camera to catch a single color the the colors must change with max rate of 15 changes per second.

It isn't colour persistence, but many LED flashlights with a single LED and high, medium and low settings do this by switching the LED on and off very fast. It is off more than it is on for the lower settings. If you turn it on and move it from side to side very fast, you can see the same effect as shown here. But when you stop moving it, it looks like a solid white light.

-
Get a camera with a flash.
You and a friend go into a dark room.
Have your friend make a face, you and the camera get close to them, and you flash them.

No, you're correct.  The ball trick is sort of the inverse.  The continuous movement of the ball looks like a stationary ring of distinct colors when he spins it because of the frequency of the light flashes in the ball and our persistence of vision.
So he's using persistence of vision with the specific frequency of flashes to create a stationary image out of a moving ball, whereas your screen is using persistence of vision and frequency to create a moving image out of a stationary screen.

Awesome illusion, but just to correct a bit: the photo receptors ("cones" in this case) don't hold the information and then transmit that info. They fire automatically, sending the signal to V1 through to V4 (occipital lobe). Sensory input in the retina is retinotropic, that is the spatial information of the stimulus is preserved in the retina and through to V4/V5. This is where the information is held for a brief amount of time and processed together. Amazing video, nonetheless.

Ok, you know what, I think I'm confusing things now.

The pixels on your screen do not work this way. Each pixel is divided into three "sections": a red one, a green one, and a blue one. Each "section" can have different intensities. The combination of different intensities of different colors very close next to each other create the colors our eyes perceive. This happens because these "sections" are very close to each other and our eyes cannot distinguish them.

Some single chip DLP projectors use a color wheel or band spinning behind the lens. It's reminiscent of the first commercial color television standard (by CBS) that used spinning color wheels in front of both the cameras and TV sets. It failed, but NBC used the CBS cameras (with a converter) for their first color TV broadcasts. Rotating color wheel cameras were used on Apollo Moon missions and the Space Shuttle into the 90's. Who'd have thought 1940's mechanical technology would last this long.

The ball isn't emitting all wavelengths at the same time, it's rapidly changing between the three colors. when he spins it you only see the ball in each position  for a fraction of a second and at that time the ball is only one color. What? Objects such as rocks and our bodies reflect certain wavelengths of light and absorb others thus appearing certain colors to our eyes. If we absorbed all light we would appear black and reflecting all would appear white. Only if an object allows light to travel through it, reflect off another object and travel back would it appear transparent. Oscillation doesn't really have anything to do with it.

@VultaGamingChannel Your eyes and brain don't actually have a specific framerate.  All of the rods and cones within your eye fire independently of one another and your brain receives a continuous stream of visual information.  The reason many of these things become blurred at high speeds is because your rods and cones require a certain amount of energy to be absorbed before they transmit a signal.  But your eyes can distinguish bright flashes of less than 1/250th of a second, or 250 fps.

Does anyone just stop to think for a moment how incredible our brains are? Our eyes receive light and our brain processes it in a specific way depending on its location and how many types of it it's receiving at the same time, and from where.. all completely seamlessly. It's amazing.

Practical application? That is how color CRTs works; they only use one beam of electrons, for each pixel it is actually hitting 3 different phosphor patches, one red one green and one blue, one at time, in sequence, but 'cause they're so small and lighting up so fast your brain puts them together.

the frame rate of the camera (25 frames per second) is such that the ball moves and changes colours while one frame is being recorded. So while the camera is recording one frame, the ball may change colour 3-4 times (in a 25th of a second)

@1veritasium - This is so simple yet interesting. 

I dont think the pc screen refresh rate is relevant in the case where you pause the video. 

If you pause the video when the ball is swinging in a circle i count about 4 "ghosts" of the ball. I imagine if you increased your camera's shutter speed by a factor of 4 or 5, you should be able to isolate a single colour of the ball per frame of video.

You might have a low light issue though because you are filming at night.

@1veritasium LED displays wouldn't be mixing the colour simultaneously, I'd assume that they are multiplexed, it would require to much wiring and processing power to be simultaneously controlling all of the LEDs. The effect shown by the ball is also how a RGB LED can display 256+ colours, they use pulse width modulation to vary the time that a colour is on for which changes the perceived brightness.
